articles.headline: In China, a Building Frenzy’s Fault Lines
articles.snippet: As foreign investors clamored for a piece of China’s real estate boom, it was easy to overlook the type of risk that brought down the property developer Kaisa.
articles.abstract: As foreign investors clamored for a piece of China’s real estate boom, it was easy to overlook the type of risk that brought down the property developer Kaisa.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the real estate market in the United States was collapsing in the mid-2000s, Wall Street went in search of new terrain, and found it in China. All across the country, from Beijing to Shenzhen, sprawling housing developments and business districts were popping up, seemingly overnight. Real estate prices were soaring. Western banks, hedge funds, private equity firms and other investors wanted a piece of the action.

articles.headline: Vaccines Face Same Mistrust That Fed Ebola
articles.snippet: The same mix of fear and distrust that helped the Ebola epidemic spread is hampering doctors conducting trials on new medicines.
articles.abstract: The same mix of fear and distrust that helped the Ebola epidemic spread is hampering doctors conducting trials on new medicines.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia — West Africa’s Ebola epidemic may be waning, but another outbreak in the future is a near certainty, health officials say.
articles.byline: By Norimitsu Onishi and Sheri Fink

articles.headline: Progress Is Slow at V.A. Hospitals in Wake of Crisis
articles.snippet: Delays in receiving care are still common, underscoring the reality that overhauling a federal department with almost 300,000 employees is a difficult and tedious process.
articles.abstract: Delays in receiving care are still common, underscoring the reality that overhauling a federal department with almost 300,000 employees is a difficult and tedious process.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — The nation’s largest hospital system has made only halting progress in hiring new doctors, replacing incompetent supervisors, upgrading outdated computers and rebuilding trust with veterans, nine months after President Obama concluded that a “corrosive culture” had led to systemic problems at hospitals run by the Department of Veterans Affairs.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Dave Philipps

articles.headline: In Mexico Oil Market, Mood Moves From Excited to Anxious
articles.snippet: As oil prices plunge, the government has scaled back its heady predictions of big-time investing while also taking steps to drum up interest.
articles.abstract: As oil prices plunge, the government has scaled back its heady predictions of big-time investing while also taking steps to drum up interest.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Mexico kicked off the opening of its oil industry to great fanfare. At a packed event at the Technology Museum here seven months ago, maps flashed on a giant screen showing dozens of oil fields that would be put up for bid to private companies for the first time in more than 75 years.

articles.headline: G.M. Settles Switch Suit, Avoiding Depositions
articles.snippet: Lawyers for the parents of Brooke Melton said General Motors agreed to settle a second lawsuit that linked her death to faulty ignitions in millions of cars.
articles.abstract: Lawyers for the parents of Brooke Melton said General Motors agreed to settle a second lawsuit that linked her death to faulty ignitions in millions of cars.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — In a notable victory for General Motors, a lawsuit that helped spur the biggest safety crisis in the company’s history has been withdrawn in exchange for a settlement from its compensation program, according to two people briefed on the agreement.

articles.headline: Guardrails Said to Pass Safety Tests
articles.snippet: Critics questioned the testing standards and pointed to the one test in which a bent piece of rail pushed a driver’s door in 6.75 inches.
articles.abstract: Critics questioned the testing standards and pointed to the one test in which a bent piece of rail pushed a driver’s door in 6.75 inches.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A potentially dangerous guardrail cleared a crucial hurdle on Friday when federal officials released their analysis of four crash tests and gave the product passing grades, even for the final test, in which the driver’s door was severely damaged.
articles.byline: By Aaron M. Kessler and Danielle Ivory

articles.headline: The Social Security Maze and Other U.S. Mysteries
articles.snippet: Many government programs are needlessly complicated, and the Social Security system is one of the worst. A new book tries to guide the unwary.
articles.abstract: Many government programs are needlessly complicated, and the Social Security system is one of the worst. A new book tries to guide the unwary.
articles.lead_paragraph: In recent years, the Boston University economist Laurence J. Kotlikoff has made something of a game — and then, eventually, an art — of cornering smart people and convincing them that they were leaving tens of thousands of Social Security dollars on the table.

articles.headline: Emails Hillary Clinton Said Were Kept Could Be Lost
articles.snippet: The former secretary of state said that her messages to other officials were preserved on government servers, but the State Department said it had failed to routinely preserve such emails.
articles.abstract: The former secretary of state said that her messages to other officials were preserved on government servers, but the State Department said it had failed to routinely preserve such emails.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Hillary Rodham Clinton this week defended her use of a personal email account to conduct State Department business, she emphasized that because she was corresponding frequently with other department officials on their government accounts, the messages were preserved on government servers.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Julie Hirschfeld Davis

articles.headline: Poles Steel for Battle, Fearing Russia Will March on Them Next
articles.snippet: Paramilitary groups in Poland have experienced sharp spikes in membership since Russia began meddling in Ukraine last year, and anxiety is apparent nationwide.
articles.abstract: Paramilitary groups in Poland have experienced sharp spikes in membership since Russia began meddling in Ukraine last year, and anxiety is apparent nationwide.
articles.lead_paragraph: KALISZ, Poland — For evidence of how much President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has jangled nerves and provoked anxiety across Eastern Europe, look no farther than the drill held the other day by the Shooters Association.

articles.headline: City Council Races Offer Change in Ferguson After Months of Upheaval
articles.snippet: In the first election of local leaders since the shooting of an unarmed black teenager, Ferguson, Mo., will vote to fill three City Council seats, and the ballot has an unprecedented number of African Americans.
articles.abstract: In the first election of local leaders since the shooting of an unarmed black teenager, Ferguson, Mo., will vote to fill three City Council seats, and the ballot has an unprecedented number of African Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — They gathered under the fluorescent lights of the First Baptist Church here one night last week to lay out visions for their battered town, four aspiring politicians, two white and two black, debating the daunting challenges of rebuilding Ferguson.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy and John Eligon

articles.headline: C.I.A. Cash Ended Up in Coffers of Al Qaeda
articles.snippet: The United States, largely because of poor oversight and loose financial controls, has sometimes inadvertently financed the very militants it is fighting.
articles.abstract: The United States, largely because of poor oversight and loose financial controls, has sometimes inadvertently financed the very militants it is fighting.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the spring of 2010, Afghan officials struck a deal to free an Afghan diplomat held hostage by Al Qaeda. But the price was steep — $5 million — and senior security officials were scrambling to come up with the money.

articles.headline: S.E.C. Wants the Sinners to Own Up
articles.snippet: In a shift to its policy, the regulator is asking for more than settlements. It wants companies and individuals to admit to their misdeeds.
articles.abstract: In a shift to its policy, the regulator is asking for more than settlements. It wants companies and individuals to admit to their misdeeds.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, the Securities and Exchange Commission has allowed companies and individuals to make settlements without admitting any wrongdoing. Even a company committing an egregious sin that cost investors millions of dollars could walk away from the proceedings without ever acknowledging its role.

articles.headline: A Young Manager for Clinton Juggles Data and Old Baggage
articles.snippet: It has fallen largely on Robby Mook, the 35-year-old who is likely to manage Hillary Rodham Clinton’s 2016 campaign, to move the Clinton machine into the modern political age.
articles.abstract: It has fallen largely on Robby Mook, the 35-year-old who is likely to manage Hillary Rodham Clinton’s 2016 campaign, to move the Clinton machine into the modern political age.
articles.lead_paragraph: On MSNBC last week, 70-year-old James Carville denounced the coverage of his old friend Hillary Rodham Clinton’s use of a personal email account at the State Department, ticking off two decades’ worth of scandals surrounding the Clintons that he attributed to an irresponsible news media.

articles.headline: Etsy’s Success Gives Rise to Problems of Credibility and Scale
articles.snippet: The online marketplace and those who use it say that imitation handmade goods, and rules restricting how popular vendors can grow, are complicating the site.
articles.abstract: The online marketplace and those who use it say that imitation handmade goods, and rules restricting how popular vendors can grow, are complicating the site.
articles.lead_paragraph: Depending on whom you ask, Alicia Shaffer, owner of the hit Etsy store Three Bird Nest, is a runaway success story — or an emblem of everything that has gone wrong with the fast-growing online marketplace for handmade goods.

articles.headline: Managers Turn to Computer Games, Aiming for More Efficient Employees
articles.snippet: BetterWorks is part of a growing office software niche that aims to whip workers into shape through compulsory competition and public scoring.
articles.abstract: BetterWorks is part of a growing office software niche that aims to whip workers into shape through compulsory competition and public scoring.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A few days before he testified in a sex discrimination lawsuit that has captivated Silicon Valley, John Doerr, arguably the most famous venture capitalist in the world, was sitting at a conference room table laying out his ideas on good management.
articles.byline: By Conor Dougherty and Quentin Hardy

articles.headline: Arab Alliance Rises as Force in Israeli Elections
articles.snippet: Israeli Arabs have experienced a political awakening as politicians have formed potent alliances that hold the potential of preventing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu from cobbling together a ruling coalition.
articles.abstract: Israeli Arabs have experienced a political awakening as politicians have formed potent alliances that hold the potential of preventing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu from cobbling together a ruling coalition.
articles.lead_paragraph: IBILLIN, Israel — Avigdor Lieberman, Israel’s nationalist foreign minister, stared coolly at the Arab politician sitting at the opposite end of a glass table during a televised election debate.

articles.headline: Many Buyers for Subprime Auto Loan Bundle
articles.snippet: Despite rising delinquencies and repossessions, Santander Consumer USA had little trouble finding buyers for a $712 million bond deal containing many automobile loans to those with tarnished credit.
articles.abstract: Despite rising delinquencies and repossessions, Santander Consumer USA had little trouble finding buyers for a $712 million bond deal containing many automobile loans to those with tarnished credit.
articles.lead_paragraph: Delinquencies on auto loans have been rising, more Americans are losing their cars to repossession, and inquiries have begun into the subprime auto industry’s lending practices.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Chasm Grows Within G.O.P. Over Spending
articles.snippet: Fiscal hawks who are determined to maintain strict spending caps oppose defense hawks who are threatening to derail any budget that does not ensure an increase for the military.
articles.abstract: Fiscal hawks who are determined to maintain strict spending caps oppose defense hawks who are threatening to derail any budget that does not ensure an increase for the military.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The congressional push this week to secure the first Republican budget plan in nearly a decade is revealing a chasm between fiscal hawks determined to maintain strict spending caps and defense hawks who are threatening to derail any budget that does not ensure an increase for the military.

articles.headline: Authorities Closing In on Hackers Who Stole Data From JPMorgan Chase
articles.snippet: Authorities anticipate capturing the architects of the JPMorgan Chase data breach, which they hope may turn the tide on such investigations, which often go unresolved.
articles.abstract: Authorities anticipate capturing the architects of the JPMorgan Chase data breach, which they hope may turn the tide on such investigations, which often go unresolved.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has become a familiar pattern: The computer system of a big American company is breached, the personal information of tens of millions of customers is stolen and a public outcry ensues. Rarely are the thieves caught.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: A Police Gadget Tracks Phones? Shhh! It’s Secret
articles.snippet: A growing number of law enforcement agencies have acquired sophisticated surveillance technology to track cellphones but have done so with an unusual restriction: They must not talk about it.
articles.abstract: A growing number of law enforcement agencies have acquired sophisticated surveillance technology to track cellphones but have done so with an unusual restriction: They must not talk about it.
articles.lead_paragraph: A powerful new surveillance tool being adopted by police departments across the country comes with an unusual requirement: To buy it, law enforcement officials must sign a nondisclosure agreement preventing them from saying almost anything about the technology.

articles.headline: Evangelicals Aim to Mobilize an Army for Republicans in 2016
articles.snippet: David Lane, a onetime Bible salesman and self-described former “wild man,” sees his mission as making evangelical Christians a decisive power in the Republican Party.
articles.abstract: David Lane, a onetime Bible salesman and self-described former “wild man,” sees his mission as making evangelical Christians a decisive power in the Republican Party.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — One afternoon last week, David Lane watched from the sidelines as a roomful of Iowa evangelical pastors applauded a defense of religious liberty by Senator Ted Cruz of Texas. That night, he gazed out from the stage as the pastors surrounded Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana in a prayer circle.

articles.headline: ‘Blurred Lines’ Lawyer Rocks Music Industry Again
articles.snippet: Richard S. Busch has made a legal specialty of winning cases that have had wide-ranging repercussions for the music industry.
articles.abstract: Richard S. Busch has made a legal specialty of winning cases that have had wide-ranging repercussions for the music industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ask Richard S. Busch, the lawyer who last week won a nearly $7.4 million copyright suit against Robin Thicke and Pharrell Williams, why he is so successful, and he will mention the 1997 film “The Devil’s Advocate,” in which Al Pacino plays Satan posing as a master lawyer.

articles.headline: Crackdown in a Detroit Stripped of Metal Parts
articles.snippet: For generations, scavengers have prowled this city with impunity. But recently, the city has been serious about fighting back, sounding a death knell for part of the underground economy.
articles.abstract: For generations, scavengers have prowled this city with impunity. But recently, the city has been serious about fighting back, sounding a death knell for part of the underground economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — It was a typical frigid winter night in this city, only now a historic blizzard was on the way. Robert Jones Jr., homeless and jobless for more than a decade, calculated his next move.

articles.headline: Netanyahu Says No to Statehood for Palestinians
articles.snippet: As Israelis go to the polls, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s stance is being seen as a push to appeal to right-wing voters. His chief challenger supports the two-state solution.
articles.abstract: As Israelis go to the polls, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s stance is being seen as a push to appeal to right-wing voters. His chief challenger supports the two-state solution.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Under pressure on the eve of a surprisingly close election, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Monday doubled down on his appeal to right-wing voters, declaring definitively that if he was returned to office he would never establish a Palestinian state.
